data.title: Rendering of TiledDrawable
data.body:
I'm having a problem with rendering a TiledDrawable. It sometimes happens that the drawable is rendered at places that exceed the size of the rect where it should actually be drawn. This is due to float precision and the way the number of times the drawable needs to be rendered is calculated.

In TiledDrawable.java ln44 there's while(x < endX). In my case x is 491.80124 while endX is 491.80127. Consequently the drawable is rendered again exceeding the actual size. Since this depends on the size of the drawable and the rect it should be rendered in I can't provide a simple test. The problem is evident though, the solution prolly simple:
Instead of subtracting the size of the drawable every time calculate the number of drawables that fit into the rect ONCE. Render the drawables. calculate remaining area/width/height by subtracting widthRect - numRenderedHorizontal*regionWidth and fill the rest with a cropped version of the drawable.

Screenshot: The problem is in the bottom right corner. The panel's border is extended to the right of the screen.
![2015-04-09 10_37_25-canyonwave](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4849383/7063141/75c1b86a-dea4-11e4-8143-6e9fbe316408.png)

data.title: Render called between pause and resume
data.body:
Today I've realized that `render()` is still called in between `pause()` and `resume()` on desktop (at least on Windows 7+8).

I think the current implementation calls pause and resume when the window loses and regains focus. In some cases that's probably a good way to be notified about those events. However in _most_ cases, I believe, it's causing problems or at least inconveniences (like being moved to a pause screen every time I switch to another window when I'm not in full-screen mode).

In two of my games I'm also taking the time between pause and resume into account of my gameplay logic. However, because the standard render(deltaTime) is still called in between pause and resume, I'm actually counting that time twice, which in one game of mine causes a doubled penalty, in the other a doubled bonus.

I don't think that people still expect render to be called after a pause (also [the lifecycle graph](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/wiki/The-life-cycle) in the wiki does not show that). And somehow I think that it's also _wrong_.

I believe that a better solution would be, to make this configurable via `LwjglApplicationConfiguration`, but _disable_ it by default. That's the default behaviour that makes sense to me the most. However, if we want to maintain backwards compatibility, we could also enable it by default (however, I really don't think that anyone actually relies on the fact, that there's a pause + resume in this case).

What do you guys think?

data.title: Make uniform names for array struct consistent across drivers
data.body:
Sadly, as far as I understand, OpenGL ES spec does not specify if first element name of struct array must be reported as `struct[0].field` or `struct.field`. Of course most driver use the first syntax but I found an Intel embed GPU driver that use the second under Windows...

SInce the spec allows it, I think this should be considered as a LibGdx bug and not a driver bug. With this PR, the name are reported without the [0] for the first element.

Note that **this PR breaks things and should not be merged** since all code using this type of behavior has to be adapted to request `struct.field` instead of `struct[0].field` (for example the 3D lighting API).

I propose it to open discussion on choosing a solution between ;
- making the proposed change in the PR (and do the API breaking change)
- don't do it and handle both type of names in all library/user code and add clear info in the Wiki.

data.title: TideMapLoader Map/Layers properties not stored
data.body:
The properties of maps and layers created with tIDE are not stored into the TiledMap object.

I've tested the following fix (with a custom Loader) :
For Map properties, edit [TideMapLoader.java L109](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/maps/tiled/TideMapLoader.java#L109)  :

```
Element properties = root.getChildByName("properties");
```

And replace by :

```
Element properties = root.getChildByName("Properties"); // Uppercase "P"
```

For Layers properties, edit [TideMapLoader.java L264](https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/blob/master/gdx/src/com/badlogic/gdx/maps/tiled/TideMapLoader.java#L264) and insert :

```
Element properties = element.getChildByName("Properties");
if (properties != null) {
    loadProperties(layer.getProperties(), properties);
}
```

In the same way, it might be great to auto-generate some basic dimensions properties on Map / Layers (width, height, tileHeight, tileWidth). If I remember well, it's already done for TmxMapLoader.

data.title: FreeTypeFontGenerator with user-supplied PixmapPacker improvements
data.body:
As discussed in #2980, I've made some changes to the PixmapPacker so that it can provide an array of TextureRegions based on its pages, and FreeTypeFontGenerator so it uses this method if the user provides their own packer as a FreeTypeFontParameter.

I've updated the PixmapPackerTest to both generate and update the TextureAtlas, to use different-sized pixmaps (and not just the same one with three different names despite creating three of them :), and to show the resulting texture atlas (change pages by hitting 0-9).

FreeTypePackTest now uses the new method.  I've also created a new FreeTypeAtlasTest which uses the less efficient (but more convenient) method of just generating the fonts directly.  I ran the tests before and after my changes on my laptop, and the times reported by those tests are comparable (but Nathan said that the performance difference would be worse on mobile).

Before my change, FreeTypePackTest
943 ms, 596 ms, 604 ms, 676 ms

After my change, FreeTypePackTest
608 ms, 666 ms, 640 ms

After my change, new FreeTypeAtlasTest
643 ms, 646 ms, 623 ms

data.title: Refactoring Window#getButtonTable
data.body:
This PR refactors really confusing thing in scene2d.ui: `Window#getButtonTable` and its override in Dialog class. In Window this method returns actual title table used for adding 'X' buttons, etc, in Dialog however it returns table for dialog buttons like 'Yes, No, Cancel'. 

Current fix is to completely remove `getButtonTable` from Window and add instead `getTitleTable`. In Dialog `getButtonsTable` was added.

If that PR can't be merged, at least some Javadoc should be added to describe what those method really return.
